Transcription for 2021466

What was the music scene like then? Newport in the early 70s?
Well, to be honest with you, I wasn't that familiar with it. I certainly wasn't part of it.
Is that because you come from A-Men Corner?
It's hard to say really. I was kind of not that interested at the time in the music. I had my teeth
into the fashion thing. A-Men Corner finished in 1970. I formed a band called Judas Jump under
Don Arden's management, which lasted only about a year and a half. We made a couple of singles and
album and then we basically decided to call it a day. It wasn't going anywhere. So I decided to come
back to Wales. I just had enough at London at the time. I was with my girlfriend, a Swedish girl
called Britt, who was lovely. I decided to come back to live in Newport for a while just to get
my thoughts together. Whilst I was there, I met up with Paul Hanbury, who was one of the partners in
the shop called Clobber that was based in Cardiff Road. He had a partner called Gerald Davis.
They were running the shop. Then I came back and I had a few quid spare. I said,
do you fancy having a partner? They agreed that I could join as a third partner. Then we developed
the shop from there and it went on. You migrated over from the music business into the fashion
business. It wasn't intended to be long term or anything. It was just something else to do.
I got fed up with the politics of the rock and roll business for a while. It was a difficult time,
especially with Arden managing and all that. Don Arden was famously Sharon Osborne's father.
He was a sink or swim kind of thing. There was a lot of money put into it. It was like a hype.
It was signed to EMI. There were hoardings in London all over the place on the tube.
There was Front Page of the NME. There was loads and loads of publicity being put out there as a
super group, which is a little bollocks really to be honest with you because we were never a super
group. He wanted to create a super group kind of band. I picked other band members from other
bands. Andy Bound from The Herd, Henry Spanetti on drums, Charlie Harrison who went on to be Poco
and a couple of other guys. One other guy, Julian Williams who became head of Sony.
Richard, you were around Newport in the early 70s I believe.
I left school in 16. I was 17 in 1970. I was living in Cardiff. It was really Cardiff that
I was familiar with during the 70s. The moon, the top rank, places like that. It wasn't until
well, I went to the Cardiff Art College in 1971. I spent a year there and then moved over to Newport
in 1972. So it was in 1972 that I arrived in Newport. You were there as well Alan in 1972?
Yeah, I was there. By then we'd opened up the shop probably in Skinner Street.
What are you making of Newport then? It was pre-punk I guess you'd call it, glam.
Where did the bands play? It was the time of Prog Rock wasn't it? I don't know about Newport
bands. I'm trying to think of the bands that would have been around at that time. You know the bands
like Oswald Orange, some odd names. They became racing cars right? Yeah, yeah. Kensington was the
club at the time. Tell us a little bit about that Alan because this would have been like almost the

was managing it and a guy called Ricky King who was the DJ and they were bringing in lots of bands.

you know a lot of the touring bands at the time they were getting the pick of the crop really.
I think they had an agent in London who was helping them out with the bands.
And didn't that eventually burn down I think? Yeah I think the only idea I don't quite know exactly
what happened. I have no idea but it was a place to go you know for sure you know it was a fun
place and it was quite happening at the time. How about you Rich? Were you a gig goer? I know you were.
Yeah well yes but it was more, the thing is we had the Students Union on Stow Hill.

well they only stopped playing because Cavern sadly died and they were the first band,
Newport band that I went and see, in fact I went to see them in Corporation Road in the Corporation
Hotel, I remember going to see it and at the back of the hotel was a hall and they used to have these
country and western nights where everybody dressed up as cowboys and took guns along,
I think they were pretend ones. What year would this have been do you think?
At 72, 3 something like that, it was early, fairly early and they would, that's where I first saw

Probably late 60s I'd say, early 70s, they had a Saturday morning club, you know, we could go,
the guy would be playing all the jive records and stuff, I mean it was really the place to go

Jerry and the Pacemakers, saw The Stones with Ike and Tina Turner, saw, you know, just reading

about 14, I think, or 15, so I mean and then the Majestic was like a regular event and it was
one of the, you know, it was very kind of either, you're either a teddy boy or a mod,
right, so there were quite often a few of argy bargies there, depending on which side of the room
you were on, it was a bit hairy, you know, but the girls were there, you know, they'd like to dance,
I was quite good at driving at the time, I remember, but I saw some great bands and like,
then I joined a band, I saw, actually I saw Sounds Incorporated playing, they were like an
instrumental band really, with six piece, with horns, and I saw the guys playing the horns,
I thought from that time onwards I really wanted to play sax, so that's why I got a saxophone,
and it went on from there, and Andy used to come up from Cardiff to see the bands.
Had he fair weather low?
Yeah, he used to come, I used to see him, and I was in a band called Five In Hand then,
and I was singing and playing a bit of sax, and Andy was always there, so I guess I got to meet him,
and it kind of went on from there, you know, but that's 60s, that's 60s, and then I promoted
stuff myself in the top rank back in 70s, but that was all, a lot of that was reggae,
I did a lot of reggae stuff, field pass, you know, third world.

And Richard, I know we haven't mentioned this, but you've kind of had a career in
tell me, tell me what you've worked in.
I've worked in housing and homelessness, and I was a psychiatric nurse, but the one thing
which I've always done is having been to art college, I always believed that everybody
ought to go to art college, and that everybody had the potential of something within them,
and I believe that when I was running this homeless organisation, that all the homeless
people that we dealt with had something that they could do.
So I raised nearly two million pounds to build the first purpose-built art centre for homeless
people in Britain.
There were day centres in Britain, but this was a purpose-built art centre.
What year was this?
That would be, it was after the 70s, unfortunately.

do something.

Well, one of the things that had happened whilst I was in Cardiff, it does follow in, it follows on to Newport, was that
we got involved with showing a film about Stokely Carmichael and the Black Panthers.
And we took it one day down to the paddle steamer in Tiger Bay.
And it was during the coal miners strike.
And halfway through the film where Stokely Carmichael was stirring everybody up, there was a power cut.
And we were the only white people in the room and the place was getting a bit, felt very hostile.
Anyway, somebody stood up with a torch and said this bloke's a bad man, really.
You know, the working class people should be standing together and all this sort of business.
Anyway, so we became good friends and we used to go down there fairly regularly as a group of students.
But it was there that I was introduced to this thing called toasting.
I'd never heard of it. I didn't know what it was.
I mean, some people now would call it rapping.
Yeah, improv.
It was toasting then. They'd have a sound system set up in the paddle steamer.
And they'd have this music playing and then somebody would just jump up and do this sort of toasting.
And then we used to go down there regularly as students and we used to enjoy it.
But when I came to Newport, there was another one of these places at the Silver Sands, which was down in Pill,
which was very near to Bolt Street, which was part of the art college.
So this was one of the sort of local places that we were using regularly on a kind of it was I seem to remember it was a Saturday night.
It was a we go there on a Saturday and then we'd go to the Hastings, which was on the other side of the road.
We'd wait until the police had raided it because it was generally a raid every week or so.
They take someone away, they get busted and then everybody collects and pay the fine.
But I mean, you'd walk down these steps into the basement and it was thick with the smoke of cannabis.
I mean, you had a choice when you got down there. Don't buy any or just get stoned.
And that's mostly what our students did because we couldn't afford to buy it.
So it was a great place for us to go to get stoned for free.
And that's where, you know, that's where I went with Woody, who became Joe Strummer.

One of the things I was hoping to kind of get out of you, if possible, because obviously Alan, you left Newport and went to Los Angeles, right?
Yeah, well, what happened with Clobber?
I got out of Clobber because we had six shops and I said to the guys, look, you know, I've discovered this thing called Punk and they didn't know anything about this.
I was so surreptitiously developing my own business there and I said, look, I'll take the shop in Bristol if you take the others.

The rent was cheap.
And that went well.
And we were getting a lot of bands and a lot of people from the valleys, kids buying their bondage jeans and all the stuff from Sex and London and all the stuff from Boy and the
Kings Road and it was just becoming quite a scene.
And there were a lot of little clubs that came off that, you know, that were very influential, I think, at the time.
And then Clive Taylor, who was the bass player with Amon Corner, was living in LA then by that time with his wife, Madeleine.
And they came over to visit his mum in Cardiff and they came in the shop and they said, wow, this is like this would go a storm in LA.

So they went we went away and then records over there, various other places.

There's going to be more to it than this.
So I went back again and I stayed this time with Clive and Madeleine and we showed me around.

I was blown away by it.

I kind of thought it was pretty cool. It was all right. I didn't have a problem.

He was in London House, which is a big department store there.

I just remember it has been, yeah, a busy town, you know, good stuff.
Lots of nice people. I don't remember a lot of aggravation really, I have to say.
I never got bothered that much.
I was going to say, when I arrived, I had to spend my first few weeks down in Bolt Street.
And I'd lived in Cardiff before anyways, and I'd gone down Tiger Bay a lot as a student in foundation.
So there were a lot of similarities between pill and Tiger Bay. But the one thing that was noticeable down there that the whole place was being about to be demolished.
And there was this absolute sense of total misery and depression.
It was the saddest place that I'd ever been to. There were people hanging around on street corners because the roads, the roads of houses have been boarded up.
And they'd been shunted out by the council to sort of stay in temporary places up in Bettis and places like that.
And they just kept returning and there was gangs of people stood on street corners. And it was very sad, you know, they opened the pill advice centre and it was run by a bloke called Cliff Knight, who went on to write lots of books about pill.
And he was a wonderful man. And they used to go in there for solace more than anything else and he used to comfort them because it was such a massive upheaval.
So Newport was going through this big change really. They were trying to sweep aside the corn exchange. A lovely building was being demolished.
I remember it was opposite the King's Head Hotel and I just couldn't understand why they were demolished. It was this fantastic building with a lovely clock front.
So funny enough, I thought it was quite depressing actually at the time. You're right, the high street was thriving. There was a fantastic market. The market was great.
I used to have a stall upstairs in the market selling art and I had a badge making business and I would make all the badges by hand.
And I made all the badges for Tizwas when that started. I jokingly sent off a couple of badges for Spit the Dog and the next programme they were all wearing them.
I used to get orders in. In fact, I'm wearing a badge now. In fact, this badge here is, I think Richard got one of these, it's for the photographs of Joe Stromer at the small cemetery.
But I made all the badges for the prizes for Tizwas and we had a lovely stall up there. It was a great sense of community. Every Saturday the upstairs was open. It was packed up there.
And the market at Crispa was wonderful. It was lovely.
In those days, before streaming and computers, you had cinemas, two channels on the TV.

What was the first IRA event at that time? Any kind of events?
Well, in London, the first IRA bombs were going off and I was working as a student up in London during the summer holidays.
And while I was working up there on one occasion, the bombs went off in the Tower of London. And on the day that I was working and I was drinking in an Irish bar in Piccadilly Circus at the time.
And they rounded up loads of people. But in the art college, we used to invite a speaker along every month to talk about various things.
And we ended up one month getting somebody from the IRA came and spoke about things. And it's a slight different perspective on their point of view.
And I actually became quite friendly with this. He was a young lad, nice young lad, who was their man in Newport.
And he used to hang around with our students. I mean, not quite sure what he was up to.
But I mean, you know, there's a big Irish population in Newport, of course, second generation, third generation, some of them.
You know, there was a lot of that. And of course, there was that bomb that went off in Newport in Gorey, which nobody was really sure whether it was just an accident that somebody had left the bomb in a case there and had to skedaddle or something.
And it went off. Could you accidentally leave a bomb? Well, a police may have turned up and he may have ran. Nobody really knows.

I know some people won't know who Alexander Cordell is so do you want to do a brief introduction about who Alexander Cordell is in the book itself. Alexander Cordell was a writer who wrote a book called Rape of the Fair Country which was published in 1959, and it tells the story
of a Welsh iron family who live in Blenavon, who get involved in Chartism, who marched down on that fateful night in 1839 to the battle that takes place outside the Westgate Hotel.
And it tells the story is the story of the family and the conditions in which they lived in and Alex felt very strongly about the working environment in which those working class people struggled to live during the 19th century and it's a fantastic story.
And I think it deserves a reissue at some point. It's been out of fashion for a while but it was always such a classic.

A sad thing is the demise of a decent local newspaper.
Yeah.
You know, back in the early 70s, you had a music correspondent, you had a police reporter, you had a reporter for practically everything you could possibly think of. It was a decent sized newspaper.
And now you've got about two or three reporters who cover everything, who never leave the office, who don't go out and speak to people, who don't get to know the people, don't feel the pulse of what's going on.
We've lost a good newspaper. It's really... and we've seen that over the last few decades, certainly since I've been here, I've noticed that.
But that's got to be the internet, right? People are not buying newspapers like they did.
